Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Plasmonics with a Twist - Chiral Nanostructures for Advanced Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The objective of this CAREER proposal is to improve the detection sensitivities of chiral molecular spectroscopy tools using the concept of plasmonic enhancement. Plasmonic nanostructures display unique optical properties that can be used to manipulate the propagation and polarization of light at a length-scale smaller than its wavelength. This research, sponsored by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry (SSMC) program, will experimentally and theoretically investigate the interactions between light, plasmons, and chiral molecules with the goal of achieving preferential optical excitation or scattering from one enantiomer over the other. The researchers will develop new fabrication methods for 3-dimensional nanoscale objects, model the polarization evolution in plasmonic systems, and demonstrate enhanced circular dichroism and optical activity in engineered metal nanoparticle-molecule complexes. Industrial collaborations will accelerate the technology transfer to pharmaceutical and analytical laboratories in industry. Undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Maryland will carry out the research activities and will be involved in outreach programs to generate excitement among the broad public towards scientific research.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Molecular "handedness", known as Chirality, is ubiquitous in Nature. The "handedness" of biomolecules leads to specific lock-and-key interactions that govern the way enzymes, receptors, DNA, RNA, etc. fold, assemble, interact and function. Mixtures of "left" and "right" chiral molecules are often unacceptable in medicinal products, as one isomer could be toxic while the other is therapeutic. The task of distinguishing between chiral molecules is not trivial, because they have the same physical and chemical properties. This project will use nanostructures with unique optical characteristics to increase the sensitivity of optical spectroscopy tools used to identify the "handedness" of biological products. These improvements will lead to higher standards in pharmaceutical product quality control, the generation of reference libraries of spectral signatures of biological products and pathogens, and better tools for the study of molecular conformations and their role in cellular regulatory functions and diseases (e.g. Alzheimer's and mad-cow). Integrated in this project is the scientific training of a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Maryland, outreach activities emphasizing student involvement in their communities, and the design of artistic displays illustrating unique optical properties of nanomaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research area of this NSF CAREER award was the experimental investigation of the interaction of optical signals (light) and plasmonic materials (nanostructures made of noble metals), in particular as they manifest themselves through and for the detection of chiral molecules (organic molecules that do not overlap with their mirror image).

The research and education activities supported by this NSF award were diverse and multidisciplinary. The award led to 5 high-profile journal publications (additional manuscripts in various stages of preparation), and a number of PI and student presentations in professional society meetings (MRS, APS, META, Metamaterials, Gordon Research Conference). The PI leveraged on collaborations with Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, industry partners (Agilent, Accustrata Inc.), the Navy Research Laboratory and the Air Force Research Laboratory to enhance the NSF award with supplementary funding and access to instrumentation and expert training for the students. The key intellectual merit contributions include the development of a robust nanofabrication scheme for 3D chiral plasmonic nanostructures with resonances in the near- and mid-infrared; the experimental and theoretical analysis of localized surface plasmon resonances in metallic nanoarcs (used as building blocks in chiral plasmonic nanostructures); circular dichroism measurements in individual 3D chiral plasmonic nanostructures by synchrotron infrared spectroscopy; characterization of nanofabrication process variations using synchrotron infrared spectroscopy; investigation of remote chemical sensing through the use of plasmonic elements in fiber optics ends; and the demonstration of second harmonic generation with individual nanostructures using resonance matching designs.

The award supported the training of 2 graduate students: A. Lawson (male, US national) completed a Masters degree and is currently part of the American STEM workforce. K. Zhang (female, international student) is expected to complete a Ph.D. degree in 2020. A.L. presented in the APS conference and receive a “Best Poster” nomination at the MRS conference. K.Z. presented in the APS conference and won 1st place in the Grad Student Poster Competition in Optics and Photonics, Optics and Photonics Conference, Optical Society at Johns Hopkins. K.Z. is also the recipient of the Ann G. Wylie Dissertation Fellowship for her work on plasmonic nanostructures. Another female student mentored by the PI won the University Distinguished Dissertation Award. The NSF award also supported (through a supplement) a staff scientist (minority, international research scientist) who contributed to two publications and is currently part of the American STEM workforce. The award also supported the mentoring of a number of undergraduate students, including 1 female and 1 resident of Puerto Rico, in hands-on Materials Science research.

In addition to the direct training provided to students in the laboratory, the PI has also integrated this NSF CAREER research program with undergraduate and graduate education during the grant period, including development of teaching materials for ENMA301 (Modern Materials Engineering), ENMA430 (Quantum Effects in Nanoscale Materials) and ENMA660 (Graduate Thermodynamics of Materials). These include video instructional material on Refraction, Electrical Conductivity Measurements, and Thermoelectric Effects; and course teaching notes for ENMA430 and ENMA660. Surveyed students expressed satisfaction with the new contributions to the course material.

The PI also established a continuing relationship with the Physics program in a public high-school in Prince George’s county and with the University of Maryland’s Center for Minorities in Science and Engineering. Through these programs the PI has visited classrooms and camps to run activities for HS students including overview talks on the field of materials science, often their first exposure to the field, and a hands-on laboratory activity on solar cell materials and physics. Over a hundred students participated in these activities. The PI has also recruited other faculty to participate in these activities and start their own.

Other broader impact activities of the PI during the period of the award include participation in scientific panels, including NSF grant review panels, APS conference organizing committees, and chairing conference symposia. The PI also wrote a commentary piece for Nature Nanotechnology and an invited review for a European Physics journal. As a member of the University of Maryland Graduate Council the PI worked to improve the mentor-mentee relationships in the Graduate School.
